body:
So I render all of my YouTube videos in 720p (HD), and it looks very good when I'm recording it, nothing is blurry or anything.
My recording software is fraps, but I have tried using Camtasia too, yet whenever I upload my videos and watch them, they always look like they are VERY low quality, even when I watch it in 720p.

Could you guys please help me with this?
I cannot find a solution no matter what I do. :'(
body_tagged:

title: Better Quality?

replies.body: Ummm delete some unneeded files and things and get a bit of room on your harddrive. And you also need a good internet :)
replies.body_tagged: Ummm delete some unneeded files and things and get a bit of room on your harddrive. And you also need a good internet :)

replies.body:
The internet has nothing to do with it, internet is only used for uploading speed. :P
I deleted all things on my computer that I didn't need a little while ago, but still the same quality :/
replies.body_tagged:

replies.body: I render my videos in movie maker, record in fraps and upload directly through youtube and they're fine. What editing software do you use?
replies.body_tagged: I render my videos in movie maker, record in fraps and upload directly through youtube and they're fine. What editing software do you use?

replies.body: I use Sony Vegas Pro 12, but I started in Movie Maker and the quality looks the exact same.
replies.body_tagged: I use Sony Vegas Pro 12, but I started in Movie Maker and the quality looks the exact same.

reply_to.body: I render my videos in movie maker, record in fraps and upload directly through youtube and they're fine. What editing software do you use?
reply_to.body_tagged: I render my videos in movie maker, record in fraps and upload directly through youtube and they're fine. What editing software do you use?

replies.body:
With movie maker don't click "Save project". Click file, go into "Save movie" and click "recommended for this project". 

You might just be saving it instead of rendering it
replies.body_tagged:

You might just be saving it instead of rendering it
